item.title: Psychosocial UFO hypothesis
item.description:
Psychosocial Hypothesis in Ufology üîó

The psychosocial hypothesis (PSH) in ufology posits that psychological and social factors best explain some UFO reports. It contrasts with the extraterrestrial hypothesis (ETH). This perspective is favored by UFO researchers in the UK, including David Clarke and Hilary Evans, and in France, following Michel Monnerie’s 1977 book. PSH researchers distinguish themselves from debunkers by maintaining a serious, albeit skeptical, interest in UFOs. The hypothesis suggests that mundane explanations combined with emotional climates distort perceptions, and that claims of contact with extraterrestrials from uninhabitable planets point to psychological processes like dreams and hallucinations.

Origin üîó

The term “psychosocial hypothesis” gained prominence in English UFO literature in 1984, with Jacques Scornaux and Peter Rogerson’s article in Magonia. Scornaux’s use of the term originated from French UFO controversies sparked by Michel Monnerie’s challenge to the ETH. Rogerson’s adoption of the term marked a shift from paranormal explanations to normal psychological processes influenced by cultural myths and social conditioning. Writers for Magonia had been exploring alternatives to the ETH since 1968, noting the failure of the ETH to account for high strangeness cases. Roger Sandell’s research on a 1905 Welsh UFO wave led him to believe that UFO reports were part of a larger complex of ghost stories and religious visions. Peter Rogerson advocated for a search for historical antecedents of UFO rumors and the social factors driving UFO flaps and social panics, noting a relationship between UFO waves and times of radical social change.

Science Fiction Aspects of the UFO Mythos üîó

Bertrand M√©heust’s discovery of parallels between UFO experience narratives and pre-1947 science fiction literature led to a study of the science fiction aspects of UFO mythology. M√©heust found numerous parallels, including wondrous effects and humanoid motives. Michel Monnerie integrated Meheust’s study into his historical critique of UFO mythology. Michel Meurger expanded Meheust’s thesis into a compendium of parallels. Jacques Vallee noted electromagnetic effects associated with UFOs in earlier fiction. Researchers have explored the cultural back-stories to various alien types, including Grays, insectoids, and reptoids. Other studies explore science fictional saucer esoterica along psychosocial and historical lines.

The Saucer Rumor üîó

The mystery of why flying saucers are the dominant shape in UFO reports was addressed by Martin Kottmeyer, who discovered that Kenneth Arnold’s initial sighting in 1947 was misinterpreted. Arnold’s description of the objects’ motion, rather than their shape, led to the “flying saucer” label. This mistake shaped the UFO phenomenon for decades, influencing film imagery, saucer photography, UFO illustration, contactee tales, and abduction experiences. Kottmeyer’s findings, first reported in 1988, suggest a cultural origin for the flying saucer phenomenon. The principal counterargument is that flying saucers were seen before Kenneth Arnold’s story, but Kottmeyer argues that the dominance of the saucer shape after 1947 is the key issue.

Flaps of Flying Phantoms üîó

Early researchers attempted to correlate UFO flaps with Mars’ proximity, but these predictions failed. British researchers shifted focus to pre-1947 “waves,” examining social, religious, political, and scientific backgrounds. Roger Sandell’s work on a 1905 Welsh UFO outbreak revealed odd facets and high strangeness material. Nigel Watson reported on a 1909 panic involving German airships spying on Britain. Phantom airship flaps were catalogued from various locations, involving cigar-shaped craft and rumors of foreign spies. By the 1930s, phantom airships were replaced by phantom aeroplanes. Researchers have experimented with variations in these explanations, such as the 1905 Wales flap occurring during a time of social change. Researchers generally reject explanations involving mass hysteria, preferring to discuss flaps as collective delusions maintained by rumor and gossip.

The Modern Myth of Jung üîó

Carl Gustav Jung’s essay Flying Saucers: A Modern Myth of Things Seen in the Skies is considered a foundational work for the PSH. Jung’s use of synchronicity has also led some to see him as a proponent of paranormal explanations. While Jung acknowledged the possibility of some UFOs being physical objects, he clarified that he was uncommitted on the issue of their reality. He expressed concern that news affirming the existence of UFOs was more welcome than skepticism.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychosocial_hypothesis

It contrasts with the extraterrestrial hypothesis (ETH) and is favored by UFO researchers in the UK and France. Proponents view UFOs as an interesting subject for study, even with skepticism.

item.title: Time-traveler UFO hypothesis
item.description:
Time-traveler UFO hypothesis üîó

The time-traveler hypothesis, also known as chrononaut UFO, future humans, extratempestrial model, and Terminator theory, proposes that unidentified flying objects (UFOs) are humans traveling from the future using advanced technology. This concept has gained recent attention from figures like retired NASA aerospace engineer Larry Lemke, Wisconsin congressman Mike Gallagher, and filmmaker Steven Spielberg. Mainstream scholars consider this hypothesis extremely implausible, and it’s generally viewed as unorthodox even among fringe conspiracy theorists.

Antecedents üîó

This section explores the origins of the ideas that led to the time-traveler UFO hypothesis.

Origins of time travel speculation üîó

This subsection traces the concept of time travel from the future to the past back to its literary origins. Pierre Boitard’s 1861 book Paris avant les hommes is credited with introducing the idea, featuring a man sent back to prehistoric Earth. Camille Flammarion’s 1887 novel Lumen also explored the theme of a soul traveling through different historical periods. The section also notes that while time travel is considered physically impossible by most, theoretical research continues to explore its potential feasibility, with scientists like J. Richard Gott and Ronald Mallet speculating on the possibility of future human time travel.

Speculation of future human evolution üîó

This subsection discusses the history of speculation about the future evolution of mankind. It highlights H.G. Wells’ The Time Machine as an early example of both time travel and speculative evolution. Other authors mentioned include Edgar Rice Burroughs, Olaf Stapledon, Kurt Vonnegut, Stephen Baxter, and Cevdet Mehmet K√∂semen. The section also identifies climate change, the technological singularity, space travel, and genetic enhancement as potential factors that could alter human evolution, leading to transhuman and posthuman scenarios.

UFOs and initial explanations üîó

This subsection provides a brief overview of the history of UFO sightings. It mentions reports of unknown objects in the skies dating back to antiquity, as well as the mystery airship sightings of the 1890s and the Foo fighters and ghost rockets during World War II. The modern UFO era is said to have begun in the summer of 1947, following Kenneth Arnold’s sighting. Initial explanations for these sightings ranged from novel US or Soviet technology to misidentification of mundane objects and mass hysteria. Fringe theories included extraterrestrial or interdimensional origins.

Formation and spread üîó

This section details the development and popularization of the time-traveler UFO hypothesis.

Implausibility of humanoid aliens üîó

This subsection addresses the common depiction of aliens as humanoids in contactee and alien abduction folklore. It cites George Gaylord Simpson’s 1964 article The Nonprevalence of Humanoids, which argues that it’s unlikely for extraterrestrial intelligence to exist and even more unlikely for it to be humanoid. The section also mentions Stephen Jay Gould’s thought experiment about rewinding evolution, suggesting that humans would likely not evolve again. Biologist Jack Cohen’s view on the implausibility of Grey aliens evolving a physiology similar to humans is also included.

Modern popularization üîó

This subsection explores the modern resurgence of the time-traveler hypothesis. It mentions Jacques Vall√©e’s 1975 book The Invisible College as an early example. Other figures and works mentioned include David S. Anderson, Jenny Randles, James Herbert Brennan, and Philip J. Corso and William J. Birnes’ The Day After Roswell, which reported Hermann Oberth’s belief that the Roswell craft could have been a time machine. The History channel series Ancient Aliens is also mentioned for its episodes exploring the concept. Michael P. Masters’ book Identified Flying Objects and The Extratempestrial Model are highlighted for their in-depth exploration of the hypothesis. Tim Peake and Steven Spielberg are mentioned for their recent public comments on the theory.

In popular culture üîó

This subsection lists examples of the time-traveler hypothesis in popular culture. It includes the TV series It’s About Time, Gregory Benford’s novel Timescape, David Drake’s novel Birds of Prey, Michael Crichton’s novel Sphere, the TV film Official Denial, the comic book series Blake and Mortimer, the band Yes, Jordan Peele’s movie Nope, and the movie Interstellar.

Terminology and connection to other theories üîó

This subsection clarifies the terminology used to describe the hypothesis, noting that while Michael P. Masters uses the term “extratempestrial,” the overall idea is often referred to as “the time-traveler hypothesis.” It also discusses the overlap between the time-traveler hypothesis and the interdimensional hypothesis, with figures like John Ventre and Harold E. Puthoff using the terms interchangeably. The section also notes that the time-traveler hypothesis provides an alternative explanation for the absence of future time travelers, similar to how the extraterrestrial hypothesis addresses Fermi’s paradox.

Criticism üîó

This section presents criticisms of the time-traveler hypothesis. It notes that the hypothesis is considered pseudoscientific. Neil deGrasse Tyson is quoted as calling the hypothesis illogical, and Robert Sheaffer criticizes Michael P. Masters’ work for relying on the belief that time travel is possible. David J. Darling argues that the extraterrestrial and time-travel hypotheses are equally unlikely and unnecessary. Ian Ridpath suggests that Jim Penniston’s claims about time-traveling UFOs may have been influenced by the film Official Denial. Isaac Arthur is mentioned for debunking the concept as presented in Ancient Aliens. Fabio Costa is quoted as saying that time travel requires two doors, one in the future and one in the past, raising the question of where the time machine is.

See also üîó

This section provides a list of related topics, including Time travel, Posthumanism, Transhumanism, Timeline of the far future, Longtermism, Speculative Evolution, Cryptoterrestrial hypothesis, Psychosocial hypothesis, Interdimensional hypothesis, and Space animal hypothesis.

item.title: Extraterrestrial UFO hypothesis
item.description:
Extraterrestrial UFO Hypothesis üîó

This article discusses the extraterrestrial hypothesis (ETH), which suggests that some unidentified flying objects (UFOs) are best explained as spacecraft or probes from intelligent extraterrestrial civilizations.

Usage of the Term üîó

This section traces the use of the term “extraterrestrial hypothesis” in UFO literature. It notes that the term gained traction in the latter half of the 1960s, with early usage attributed to French ufologist Jacques Vall√©e in his 1966 book. Other figures who used the term in the late 1960s include Aim√© Michel, James E. McDonald, and James Harder. Physicist Edward Condon is credited with popularizing the term and its abbreviation “ETH” in 1969 when presenting the findings of the Condon Report. Skeptic Philip J. Klass also used the term in his 1968 book.

Chronology üîó

This section explores the historical context leading up to the modern ETH. It traces the origins of the idea of extraterrestrial life and visitation to earlier concepts, including Percival Lowell’s theories about Martian canals and ancient Martian civilizations, the science fiction writings of H. G. Wells and Edgar Rice Burroughs, and the works of Emanuel Swedenborg, who linked other worlds to the afterlife. It also mentions Charles Fort, who collected accounts of anomalous aerial phenomena in the early 20th century and theorized about visitors from other worlds. The modern ETH, linking unidentified aircraft to alien life, took root in the late 1940s and 1950s, influenced by pseudoscience and popular culture, and bolstered by unexplained sightings investigated by governments and civilian groups.

Historical Reports of Extraterrestrial Visits üîó

This section presents examples of early speculation about extraterrestrial visitors. It mentions a French newspaper story from 1864 about the discovery of an alien-like creature inside an egg-shaped structure. It also discusses H. G. Wells’ “The War of the Worlds” (1898), which popularized the idea of Martian visitation and invasion. The section notes a surge in “mystery airship” reports in the late 19th century, with some speculating about Martian origins. It also mentions the influence of comic strips, radio shows, and movies like Buck Rogers and Flash Gordon in popularizing the idea of alien visitation in spaceships. Orson Welles’ 1938 radio broadcast of “The War of the Worlds” caused some public panic.

The 1947 Flying Saucer Wave in America üîó

This section focuses on the events surrounding the Kenneth Arnold sighting in 1947 and the subsequent “flying saucer” craze. It details Arnold’s initial report of seeing unidentified disk-shaped aircraft near Mount Rainier and his consideration of the possibility of extraterrestrial origins. The section notes the widespread speculation in newspapers about the nature of the “saucers,” including theories about secret military projects, Russian spy devices, hoaxes, optical illusions, and mass hysteria. It mentions Senator Glen Taylor’s comment about wishing the saucers were spaceships from another planet and R. DeWitt Miller’s suggestion that they could be vehicles from Mars or other dimensions. The section also cites journalist Edward R. Murrow’s observation that the ETH did not gain widespread attention until about 18 months after Arnold’s sighting.

Evolution of Public Opinion üîó

This section examines how public opinion regarding UFOs and the ETH evolved. It mentions the release of the first U.S. poll of public UFO perceptions by Gallup in August 1947, which showed that most people either had no opinion or believed there was a mundane explanation for the sightings. The section also discusses the influence of movies depicting flying saucers and aliens in the early 1950s. It cites a poll published in Popular Science magazine in 1951, which reported that most UFO witnesses believed they had seen a man-made aircraft. By 1957, 25% of Americans were willing to believe in the ETH. A Roper poll in 2002 reported that 56% of respondents thought UFOs were real, with 48% believing that UFOs had visited Earth.

Religion üîó

This section briefly mentions the connection between UFOs and religion, citing the Aetherius Society, founded by George King in 1955, as one of the first and most enduring UFO cults.

NASA üîó

This section discusses NASA’s evolving stance on UAPs. In June 2021, NASA Administrator Bill Nelson directed NASA scientists to investigate Unidentified Aerial Phenomenon, exploring the possibility that UAP could represent extraterrestrial technology. NASA scientist Ravi Kopparapu advocates studying UAP with an agnostic approach, involving experts from various fields to collect data and deduce the identity of such UAP. In August 2021, Kopparapu presented a paper supporting ETH.

Private or Government Studies üîó

This section presents examples of private or government studies that have concluded in favor of the ETH or have had members who disagreed with official conclusions. It mentions a 1948 Top Secret USAF Europe document citing Swedish air intelligence’s conclusion that some UFOs had extraterrestrial origins. It also discusses the USAF Project Sign’s 1948 Top Secret Estimate of the Situation, which concluded that the ETH was the most likely explanation for the most perplexing unexplained cases. The section mentions a secret West German study from 1951 to 1954, headed by Hermann Oberth, which also concluded that UFOs were extraterrestrial. It also discusses the CIA’s internal scientific review of UFOs in the early 1950s, noting that some CIA scientists were seriously considering the ETH. The section mentions extraterrestrial “believers” within Project Blue Book, including Major Dewey Fournet and consultant J. Allen Hynek, who later became a staunch supporter of the ETH. It also cites statements from former CIA Director Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter, who urged Congressional action to reduce the dangers from secrecy about unidentified flying objects. The section mentions Greek physicist Paul Santorini’s claim that a 1947 Greek government investigation into the European Ghost rockets concluded that they were extraterrestrial. It also discusses the 1968 Condon Report, noting that many members of the study disagreed with Condon’s methods and biases. The section mentions the 1999 private French COMETA report, which concluded that the hypothesis of extraterrestrial visitors best accounted for the facts. It also discusses Jean-Jacques Velasco, the head of the official French UFO investigation SEPRA, who stated that 14% of the cases studied by SEPRA were ‘utterly inexplicable and extraterrestrial’ in origin.

Critical Responses and Positions of the ETH üîó

This section presents critical responses to the ETH. It notes that there is no scientific proof to back up assertions of alien encounters. It states that despite ardent believers, no rigorous analysis has ever concluded that various UFO sightings are verifiable evidence for the ETH.

U.S. Military Investigation and Debunkery üîó

This section discusses the U.S. military’s investigation of UFOs and its efforts to debunk the ETH. It mentions the formation of Project Sign in 1947, the first official U.S. military UFO study. It notes that Project Sign concluded without endorsing any unified explanation for all UFO reports, and the ETH was rejected by USAF Chief of Staff General Hoyt Vandenberg. The section also discusses the CIA’s Robertson Panel, which was organized in 1953 to review the Blue Book’s best evidence and recommend an official policy of public debunkery.

Involvement of Scientists üîó

This section examines the scientific community’s response to the ETH. It notes that the scientific community has shown very little support for the ETH, largely accepting the explanation that UFO reports are the result of misinterpretations or hoaxes. It mentions Stephen Hawking’s skepticism about the ETH. The section cites Carl Sagan’s observation about the emotional nature of the idea of extraterrestrial visitation and the potential for self-deception. It also quotes Peter A. Sturrock’s statement about the narrow polarization of the UFO debate around the ETH. The section presents the results of a 1973 poll of American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics members, which found that about 10% believed that UFOs were vehicles from outer space. It also presents the results of a 1977 poll of American Astronomical Society members, which asked them to assign probabilities to eight possible explanations for UFOs. The section summarizes the primary scientific arguments against ETH, as outlined by J. Allen Hynek, including the failure of surveillance systems to detect UFOs, gravitational and atmospheric considerations, statistical considerations, the behavior of UFOs and their occupants, the isolation of the UFO phenomenon in time and space, the space unworthiness of UFOs, and the problem of astronomical distances.

Fewer Sightings Despite Camera Phone Technology üîó

This section discusses the argument that the proliferation of smartphone camera technology has not led to a significant increase in recorded UFO sightings, calling into question the claimed phenomenology of UFOs.

NASA üîó

This section presents NASA’s official standpoint on the ETH, which is that it lacks empirical evidence. It quotes David Morrison’s statements that no one has ever found a single artifact or any other convincing evidence for alien visits and that no claims of UFOs as being alien craft have any validity.

CIA üîó

This section mentions the CIA’s organization of the January 1953 Robertson Panel of scientists to debunk the data collected by the Air Force’s Project Blue Book.

item.title: UFO religion
item.description:
UFO Religion üîó

A UFO religion is a religion where belief in extraterrestrial entities operating unidentified flying objects (UFOs) is a core element. Adherents typically believe these ETs are interested in humanity’s welfare and that humanity will eventually join an existing ET civilization. Some UFO religions incorporate ETs into a supernatural worldview, blurring the lines between aliens and angels. These religions draw inspiration from early science fiction, ufology, UFO sightings, and alien abduction stories. The Aetherius Society, founded by George King, is considered the first UFO religion.

Summary üîó

Adherents believe that the arrival or rediscovery of alien civilizations, technologies, and spirituality will enable humans to overcome ecological, spiritual, and social problems. Issues like hatred, war, bigotry, and poverty are believed to be resolvable through superior alien technology and spiritual abilities. These belief systems are often millenarian in their outlook.

UFO religions developed in countries like the United States, Canada, France, the United Kingdom, and Japan, where technology is advanced enough to conceive of ETs and where religion is not suppressed. The term “flying saucers” and the popular notion of the UFO originated in 1947. The study of UFO religions by sociologists, historians, theologians, scholars of religious studies, and new religious movements began in the 1950s.

Notable UFO Religions üîó

UFO religions generally involve belief in communication with extraterrestrial beings through physical contact, telepathy, and astral projection. These groups often believe that humanity will be saved by aliens who will educate humans on a better way to live or take believers to a more positive location. Extraterrestrial beings are often seen pleading with humanity to improve itself and move away from greed and violence. UFO religions emphasize spiritual growth and the evolution of humanity. A UFO religion can form before or after an individual claims to have experienced an alien abduction.

J. Gordon Melton identifies the “I AM” Activity, founded by Guy Ballard, as the first UFO religion, although Christopher Hugh Partridge views it as a theosophical religion. Partridge notes that UFO religions believe the supreme being or “evolved entity” came from another plane or planet. The 1947 Roswell incident is a key point in time within UFO spirituality. James R. Lewis notes that Ufologists see it as the date of the “emergence of UFOs into the public consciousness.” Partridge places UFO religion within the context of theosophical esotericism and asserts that it began to be associated as “UFO religion” after the Roswell incident. He notes that most UFO religions still have many of the key points associated with Theosophy, such as belief in the same Spiritual Hierarchy, and he also draws parallels to New Age thought.

Stephen Hunt describes the Aetherius Society, founded by George King in 1955, as “probably the first and certainly the most enduring UFO cult.” Hunt places the Aetherius Society and Ra√´lism among the “most renowned” of the “flying saucer cults.” Melodie Campbell and Stephen A. Kent place the Aetherius Society and Unarius as among the “oldest and most studied” of the flying saucer cults. They describe Heaven’s Gate and Order of the Solar Temple as the “most controversial groups combining UFO belief with variations of contactee assertions.” Gregory L. Reece classes Scientology as a “UFO group,” discussing elements of the Xenu cosmogony and Space opera in Scientology doctrine. He compares Scientology to the Aetherius Society and Ashtar Command. Victoria Nelson writes that “[t]he most prominent current UFO religion is probably the science fiction writer L. Ron Hubbard’s Church of Scientology.”

item.title: Bill Moore (ufologist)
item.description:
William L. Moore (Ufologist) üîó

William Leonard Moore, born October 31, 1943, is an author and former UFO researcher who gained prominence from the late 1970s to the late 1980s. He is best known for co-authoring two books with Charles Berlitz, including The Roswell Incident.

Career üîó

Moore’s interest in UFOs began in his teenage years. He graduated from Thiel College in Greenville, Pennsylvania, in 1965. After teaching language and humanities at various high schools, he became the Arizona state section director of the Mutual UFO Network (MUFON). He then transitioned to a career as a freelance writer.

He co-authored The Philadelphia Experiment - Project Invisibility with Charles Berlitz in 1979, which explored the alleged naval military experiment aboard the USS Eldridge in 1943. In 1980, Moore and Berlitz co-wrote The Roswell Incident, which claimed that the Roswell UFO incident involved the crash of an extraterrestrial spacecraft.

In May 1987, Moore, along with ufologists Jaime Shandera and Stanton Friedman, circulated the Majestic 12 documents, which purported the existence of a high-level policy-making group overseeing UFOs and extraterrestrials.

At a 1989 MUFON conference, Moore admitted to engaging in “disinformation” activities against Paul Bennewitz on behalf of the Air Force Office of Special Investigations.

Critical Reception üîó

The Philadelphia Experiment - Project Invisibility has been largely dismissed as an unsubstantiated urban myth. The Roswell Incident has been criticized as a collection of hearsay and unwarranted speculation. Critics have also pointed fingers at Moore regarding the fraudulent nature of the Majestic 12 documents.

Books üîó

  • The Philadelphia Experiment Project Invisibility (1979)
  • The Roswell Incident (1980)
